entry.title: SAP BTP Guidance Framework: Center of Expertise (CoE), Administration and DevOps
entry.content:
As outlined in the blog post SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators from Cecily Sorenson (@cecilysorenson), the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a practical framework for anyone using SAP BTP. In this blog post, let's focus especially on the organizational setup and the role and tasks of an administrator. 

Overview of SAP BTP Guidance Framework - and focus of this blog post

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework brings a lot to get you started! 

 

Organizational Setup 

One main question faced in almost every SAP BTP project is on the best organizational setup to ease a smooth onboarding, reduce time to value and to operate the platform effectively. One key aspect can be the founding of a central platform engineering team or a Center of Expertise (CoE) that is responsible for such topics as account operations, infrastructure, central governance and compliance - and for driving the overall cloud adoption across the organization. 

A CoE can make the difference and help your cloud development teams to transition towards a cloud-centric mindset and processes, as the provided guidance allows them to focus more on providing business value without having to bother about finding, implementing and running the right infrastructure and processes. 

Therefore, it should be no surprise that the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers guidance here as well, in the form of the SAP BTP Center of Expertise (CoE) Guide. 

The guide provides a comprehensive framework for establishing and scaling an SAP BTP CoE. For example, it gives a definition of a CoE, outlines a corresponding maturity model, explains roles and responsibilities, and gives practical guidance on how to implement it along the lifecycle. 

Overview of maturity model explained in the SAP BTP CoE Guide

 

Administrating the Platform and the Lifecycle 

To learn more about actual tasks and responsibilities for administrating the platform itself and for handling the lifecycle of your applications and use cases running on it, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers the SAP BTP Administrator's Guide. 

Understand basic concepts and tasks, before benefitting from guidance and best practices along topics such as: 

  • Your account model 
  • Delivering your applications and changes towards your runtime with the right mix of agility and control 
  • Operating your applications on SAP BTP, with a combination of central observability (to get aware of how your business scenarios are behaving) and local observability tools for root cause analysis in case of issues or performance degradations 

This also comprises check lists, examples and guidance. For example, here’s an example for an individual account model: 

Picture of an exemplary account model for SAP BTP

 

DevOps with SAP BTP 

When transitioning to the cloud, you want to benefit from modern development principles in the spirit of DevOps. But how does this fit to stricter boundary conditions faced in an enterprise environment? 

Here, the SAP BTP Guidance Framework also has you covered - by offering a description how to enable your development teams to benefit from tight feedback loops offered by automated build and test pipelines ("Continuous Integration") in combination with the right level of control for the delivery towards production. 

Overview of DevOps approach with SAP BTP

For this, your development teams can use pipeline templates to set up a running build and test pipeline for typical SAP BTP development use cases - thanks to our opinionated "Pipeline-as-a-Service" approach, they can set them up in minutes and run them with crucially reduced cognitive load. These pipelines then can qualify the development changes in terms of provided functionality, usage of outdated libraries, code issues, and other compliance-relevant aspects, as needed by your business. 

As soon as your development teams come up with correspondingly qualified release candidates, they can easily switch on in the pipeline the automated handover of the changes into a central, reliable transport and change management approach. Here, your administration team can centrally define delivery landscapes, including permissions on who is allowed to come up and handle changes where and a central log file for auditing reasons. This can be decoupled from the development teams who only need to know the entry node to the delivery, using a clearly defined hand-over process from qualified agile development into controlled delivery towards production.  

With a simple integration of transport management into SAP's central operation platforms, this can even be extended to central change management processes, to handle interdependencies of changes from different environments by centrally orchestrating their propagation across SAP BTP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP cloud solutions. All this can be enriched with additional release planning and management capabilities. 

 

Summary 

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework has a lot to offer also for administrators – from a framework to forge your organizational setup to guidance on how to handle the lifecycle of your applications and use cases on SAP BTP and on how to combine agile development with the right level of control over changes in your runtime environment. 

If you should have feedback on the documents and offerings mentioned above, please let us know – ideally by providing feedback in SAP Help Portal, as described for example here: SAP BTP Documentation Goes GitHub - New Collaborat... - SAP Community

entry.title: SAPinsider EMEA 2025 in Three Easy Steps
entry.content:
Returning for a third year in succession, SAPinsider EMEA 2025 will open it’s doors at the Tivoli Hotel in Copenhagen next week on 1st October. And I know that the SAP team is all set and ready to go, having spent the past few months working on content and exhibition planning for this annual conference.

And with the inside scoop on our session plan this year, I also know that we have a lot to talk about and share with the many SAP customers and business partners who are planning to attend this year. So l for one am looking forward to our third outing here, in the charming city of Copenhagen.

So, in what has now become an annual event in itself, I am writing this blog to give you a sneak peek of SAP’s conference plans, and how to make the most of the event in three easy steps. And yes, of course, this will include details of my personal top picks for must-see SAP sessions!  

Step 1: Plan Ahead

As a conference attendee you’ll be invited to download the latest SAPinsider event app before you travel to Copenhagen, so my advice is do install this before you go and then spend some time whilst travelling selecting sessions and adding them to your personal agenda. Don’t leave this until you get there – you'll find yourself busy with sessions and conversations, and very little time for planning. So pre-planning is always best, and then you’ll arrive with a purpose, and ready to make the most of the educational and networking opportunities available.

To give you a head-start, here are some ideas for sessions to see, and my personal top picks:

  1. The keynotes – yes, both of them! In the day 1 keynote, SAP’s Jorrit de Groot will share insights on how customers are partnering with SAP to leverage SAP Business Suite to overcome key business challenges. On day 2 the keynote will focus on NOVO Nordisk’s experience of their own transition to SAP S/4HANA. With lots of practical advice offered in both keynote sessions, I’m sure these will be of great interest to anyone considering or already involved in their own business transformation project.
  2. Conference sessions. There’s a lot to choose from, however here are five sessions from the SAP team to add to your agenda:
    1. Transforming Finance with AI: What's Here, What's Next, and How to Prepare
    2. AI Won't Take Your Job—But Someone Using It Might
    3. Unlocking Growth and Agility with SAP's Two-Tier Cloud ERP Model
    4. SAP Business Data Cloud: Product Overview, Updates, and Roadmap
    5. SAP Integration Suite: Product Strategy, Innovations, and Roadmap
  3. Hands-on-Labs. Get up close and personal with SAP solutions, in these three sessions:
    1. Extend SAP S/4HANA (Cloud ERP) with SAP Build While Keeping the Core Clean
    2. Modernize Enterprise Integrations Across Hybrid Landscapes with SAP Integration Suite
    3. The SAP Security Game

And of course there are many other sessions, including customer case stories, listed on the event agenda too.

Step 2: Network with peers and industry experts

Another “not to be missed” opportunity at SAPinsider is the chance to network with industry peers, SAP business partners and the SAP team. This event never fails to deliver as an excellent networking opportunity, and I for one will be taking my time to make the most of it.

In terms of networking, I along with several colleagues will be helping to support the SAP exhibit booth at the event this year, so why not come along to say hello and have a chat at our new-look exhibit booth? We're really looking forward to having some great conversations with event attendees this year, so please don’t be shy, join us at the SAP booth and ask any questions you might have…and in addition you can also voice your opinion too, as we’re once again offering you the chance to tell us what you think about SAP solutions, as we’re partnering again with Trust Radius, who will be taking product reviews at the SAP booth too.

Step 3: Make the most of your free time…but continue those conversations!

Conference days are busy, and if you make the most of them you’ll find yourself in need of some rest and relaxation…but not too much of course, you’re still there to work after all! So if you're thinking of using the free time you have to take in the sights, sounds and tastes of Copenhagen, then why not consider planning for some out of conference meetings with colleagues, peers, partners and the SAP team when they’re “off the clock”, and continue your networking conversations over evening dinner, or whilst taking that stroll by the Nyhavn Canal.

See you there!

For those of you travelling to Copenhagen, I do hope that you find SAPinsider EMEA 2025 to be a truly rewarding experience. Remember to take time to create an agenda in the event app, and of course if you visit the show floor then look me up at the SAP exhibit booth.

Safe travels and see you in Copenhagen!

Chris Grundy

Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: 5 Things You Didn’t Know About SAP Joule for Developers — Plus an Exciting Update
entry.content:
Artificial intelligence is reshaping how we work, and developers are among the first to feel the impact. SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of AI capabilities in SAP Build and ABAP Environment designed to help developers build smarter, faster, and more intuitively — whether you’re streamlining repetitive coding tasks or creating complex integrations. 

And here’s the big news: 
👉The free promotion for SAP Joule for Developers has been extended. 

That means you now have even more time to explore Joule, experiment with projects, and see firsthand how it can transform your workflows — all at no cost. 

We are hosting an engaging webinar with demos, use cases and best practices on how to maximize value with Joule in SAP Build. Read till the end to find the registration link!

Without further ado, here are five things you might not know about SAP Joule for Developers. 

 

1. It’s More Than Just an AI Assistant 

Many developers see Joule as just a chatbot. But it’s far more powerful. Joule for Developers goes beyond simple answers — it integrates into your workflow, generates context-aware code suggestions, and automates repetitive tasks. Whether you’re building in SAP Build, working in ABAP, or connecting with third-party services, Joule is designed to keep your productivity high. 

👉Learn more about capabilities via our webpage 

 

2. It Speaks “Developer” Fluently 

Joule understands technical prompts and adapts its recommendations to your specific context. Describe what you want to create, and Joule can generate API calls, reusable code snippets, or even integration patterns tailored to your environment. 

👉Explore a tutorial in ABAP here. 

 

3. Built-In Security and Compliance Awareness 

SAP Build—with SAP Joule for Developers embedded—is built on enterprise-grade security. It adheres to SAP’s compliance standards, so your code and data are always protected. You can confidently experiment with AI in your workflows, backed by privacy, governance, and regulatory safeguards. 

👉Read more about SAP’s approach to security and compliance in SAP Build and SAP Business Technology Platform. 

 

4. It Helps You Learn as You Build 

Joule isn’t just about solutions — it’s about learning. As you code, Joule explains the why behind its suggestions. This helps developers discover new frameworks, understand best practices, and ramp up on unfamiliar technologies faster. 

Think of it as a mentor who’s always available, providing guidance while letting you stay in the driver’s seat. 

👉Try a tutorial on how to create CAP application in SAP Build. 

 

5. It Works Across Your Development Stack 

Joule isn’t limited to a single tool or environment. Whether you’re generating processes or building applications, SAP Joule for Developers can support you. This flexibility means you can bring AI assistance into the environments you already know — without having to change how you work. 

 

Free Access to SAP Joule for Developers 

Now is the best time to explore, innovate, and see how Joule can transform the way you build — without worrying about cost. 

👉Get started today.  

📅Mark your calendar: Join our upcoming SAP Build with Joule webinar on September 24th to see live demos, best practices, and how to maximize the value of Joule in your projects. Register here.

entry.title: Introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
We are pleased to share that SAP HANA Cloud is now generally available on SAP BTP powered by SAP Cloud Infrastructure. This new deployment option complements our existing offerings on hyperscaler platforms, addressing the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control.

About SAP Cloud Infrastructure

SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) is SAP's own Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platform, operated from SAP data centers around the globe. Built on OpenStack APIs, it provides hyperscale-like capabilities including compute, storage, and networking. Originally designed to run SAP cloud applications with high scalability, resilience, compliance, and security, SCI now also supports selected customer and partner workloads. To explore the platform and its features, visit the SAP Cloud Infrastructure Documentation.

How the new deployment fits into SAP's multi-cloud strategy

SAP gives customers the flexibility to run SAP HANA Cloud on the infrastructure that best meets their needs. Today, it's available on the leading hyperscalers—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Alibaba Cloud—leveraging our partners' global reach and modern infrastructure. See SAP HANA Cloud data centers.

By adding SAP Cloud Infrastructure as a deployment option alongside the hyperscalers, we give customers even more choice and flexibility, while meeting requirements for technological autonomy, data residency, and access control in the public cloud.

First region and initial scope

SAP HANA Cloud is now live in the SAP BTP Europe (Frankfurt) region on SCI. This cloud-in-country deployment keeps customer and backup data local, ensuring data residency and compliance.

Operating in EU Access mode, the SCI-based deployment restricts the processing of personally identifiable customer data to SAP delivery units located within the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, giving customers enhanced control and data protection.

On SCI, SAP HANA Cloud delivers the same capabilities and benefits as on hyperscalers*, along with the same SLAs and pricing models, ensuring a consistent experience regardless of deployment choice.

What's next?

SAP HANA Cloud is expanding alongside SAP BTP into new SCI regions. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases—check the latest SAP HANA Cloud data center availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Summary

With SAP HANA Cloud, customers can choose the infrastructure provider that best fits their business—either a partner hyperscaler or SAP itself. The first SAP BTP region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is Europe (Frankfurt). With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region provides compliance, security, and reliability, serving the specific needs of German and European customers.

*Restrictions at GA: (1) SAP HANA Cloud, Data lake Relational Engine, (2) Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central, (3) Customer-managed encryption keys (CMK), and (4) memory sizes larger than 7.5 TB.

entry.title: Issue and Send Verifiable Credentials
entry.content:
In the evolving landscape of digital ecosystems, verifiable credentials (VCs) have emerged as a powerful tool for establishing trust and enabling secure data sharing. This article outlines the process by which an issuer can create and issue a verifiable credential with SAPs BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification based on a predefined schema, ensuring consistency and authenticity. Following issuance, the credential is securely transferred to the holder, who can use it to participate in a dataspace. For example, within the Catena-X dataspace - a collaborative network enabling trusted data sharing in the automotive and manufacturing sectors - the holder could present their VC to identify themselves in a data sharing use case, ensuring secure and seamless interaction.

Pre-Conditions for Issuance 

Before issuing a verifiable credential, several pre-conditions related to the participating entities, credential configuration, and schema setup must be fulfilled.

  1. A Holder Tenant with an Identity (DID) and Trust List Configuration. The holder, who will receive and own the verifiable credential, must have a valid Decentralized Identifier (DID). This DID uniquely represents the holder within the system, enabling them to securely interact with the issuer and verifiers. Additionally, the issuer’s DID must be added to the holder’s trust list. The trust list is critical as it ensures that the holder only accepts verifiable credentials from selected issuers. For example, in Catena-X, this ensures that only accredited organizations acting as trusted credential issuers can issue verifiable credentials to participants.
  2. An Issuer Tenant with an Identity (DID). The issuer, as mentioned earlier, must have a valid DID representing their secure digital identity. This DID is essential for signing and legitimizing the verifiable credentials, allowing other participants in the ecosystem to independently validate their authenticity and trustworthiness. 
  3. A Schema for the Verifiable Credential. The verifiable credential should adhere to a defined schema that specifies its structure and attributes. The schema serves as a standardized blueprint, ensuring that the data within the credential such as names, dates, or unique identifiers is understood and interoperable across all parties in the ecosystem. 
  4. Configure the Issuer: Once the schema is created, the issuer must configure the credential type that they will issue based on that schema. For each credential type the issuer can specify whether the credential requests are processed automatically or manually and if it is tied to its predefined schema. 

Issue Verifiable Credentials

  1. Navigate to credential section and click on the Issue button to start the issuance process.
  2. Configure meta data of the verifiable credential (validity settings and choose signing dentity)


    • Set Expiration: Enter the expiration date and time for the VC (how long the credential will be valid)
    • Revocation List (Optional): If the credential should be revocable, enable the option to assign it to a revocation list and select the appropriate revocation list if more than one exists.
    • Signing Identity: Select the DID (Decentralized Identifier) under your control that will be used to sign the credential. 

  3. Add additional contexts (advanced): Additional contexts allow interoperability with extended schemas or domain-specific vocabularies.

  4. Define credential details


    • Select a credential type supported by your issuer, published via the issuer metadata endpoint. These types can be configured in the issuer settings. Holders may only accept specific credential types from your issuer, so choose accordingly.
    • Select Schema: Choose the schema that defines the structure and required attributes of the credential. The holder’s wallet will use this schema to validate and display the credential.
    • Fill in Mandatory Attributes: Based on the schema, a dynamic form will be displayed. Enter all required attributes (e.g., name, date of birth, license number). Ensure all fields marked as mandatory are filled; incomplete credentials may be rejected by the holder. Add any additional, non-mandatory attributes as needed.

  5. Finalize verifiable credential:


    • Immediate signing of the verifiable credential or in a later point in time
    • Immediate or deferred offer: Decide if the credential should be offered to the holder immediately after signing or stored for future delivery.

The verifiable credential is now created and can be sent directly to the holder, or, if preferred, stored and delivered upon the holder’s request at a later time. All issued credentials are visible to the issuer within the wallet, allowing the issuer to select an issued credential in the future for purposes such as revocation or re-offering to the holder.

API

The same process described in the user interface can also be performed programmatically using the API, which provides an endpoint for the combined creation, signing, and offering of credentials in a single call, or, alternatively, allows you to perform these steps individually with separate API calls.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "Dataspace",
    "payload": {
      "offer" : {
        "content": {
            "@context": [
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
            ],
            "name": "BPN",
            "description": "BPN",
            "expirationDate": "2025-11-25T16:51:22.000Z",
            "type": [
                "BpnCredential"
            ],
            "issuer": "{issuerDID}",
            "credentialSubject": {
                "id": "{holderDID}",
                "bpn": "BPNL000000002"
            },
            "credentialStatus": {
                "id": "{revocation list}",
                "type": "StatusList2021"
            }            
        }, 
        "signature": {
          "proofMechanism": "external",
          "proofType": "jwt"
        }
      }
    }
}

Next step: 

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help:  Issuing Verifiable Credentials
  • API documentation in detail

entry.title: Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts
entry.content:
SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) is SAP’s solution for enabling Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI). With DIV, organizations can establish trusted digital identities, issue and manage verifiable credentials, and empower organizations with secure digital interactions. To help you get started with DIV and explore its full potential, we have published a comprehensive series of blog posts covering setup, configuration, usage, and practical SSI use cases.

Below you will find a categorized list of these blogs for easy navigation:

  1. Setting Up Your SSI Environment
    1. Provisioning SAP’s Self-Sovereign Identity Wallet: This blog post will guide you through the process of creating a tenant of the DIV using SAP’s provisioning admin dashboard or API.

  2. Using DIV
    1. Preparing an SSI Wallet for a Holder: In today’s interconnected digital landscape, secure and decentralized identity management is crucial for seamless and trusted data exchange. To facilitate this, SAP provides DIV, a Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) wallet solution that enables organizations to participate in SSI use cases.
    2. Creating an SSI Wallet for an Issuer: SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification service enables organizations to manage and verify digital identities securely. While the Holder Wallet is primarily used to receive and present verifiable credentials, it can be extended to issue verifiable credentials as well.
    3. Configure the Trust List: A trust configuration is a declarative policy, defining trusted entities (issuers). This configuration typically includes the trusted issuers' decentralized identifiers (DIDs) and optionally a list of credential types.
    4. Issue and Send Verifiable Credentials: This article outlines the process by which an issuer can create and issue a verifiable credential with SAPs BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification based on a predefined schema, ensuring consistency and authenticity.
    5. Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP): This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.
  3. Use Case Descriptions
    1. Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces: A data space is a secure, decentralized framework that enables organizations to share and collaborate on data while keeping control. The exchange of data between companies within a dataspace ecosystem is essential an is securely enabled with the help of DIV.
    2. Using Self-Sovereign Identity and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection: In the fast-evolving semiconductor industry, understanding market demand is both critical and challenging. Modern data spaces offer new opportunities for more targeted and privacy-preserving demand collection. One innovative approach combines Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and verifiable credential (VC) vouchers to streamline questionnaire management within these data spaces.

Explore these resources to learn how SAP DIV can power your journey toward trustworthy, decentralized digital identity and unlock new business value with SSI.

Read more

  • SAP help
  • API documentation

entry.title: Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP)
entry.content:
In the era of Self-sovereign Identity (SIS), verifiable credentials (VCs) are becoming a cornerstone. Organizations and individuals can now issue, request, and present attestations  without relying on a central authority, enabled by emerging standards and protocols such as the Decentral Claims Protocol (DCP). This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.

 

Two VC Transfer Patterns

With DCP, there are two main patterns for moving a verifiable credential from the issuer's environment to the holder's:

Holder-Initiated Credential Request

Holder requests VCs:

  • The holder launches their VC request app and picks the issuer from which they wish to request credentials.
  • The app pulls published credential types (from the issuer's metadata endpoint), ensuring the holder can only request credentials the issuer offers. 

     
  • The users selects the credential types to be requested
  • Next, the holder selects which identity to use (think multiple DIDs or personas in their wallet).
  • A request for the selected credential type(s), tied to the chosen identity, is dispatched to the issuer.

 

API to Request VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/requestCredentials/{app_name}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "requestedCredentials": [
    {
      "credentialType": "BpnCredential",
      "format": "vcdm11_jwt"
    }
  ],
  "issuerDid": "{issuerDID}",
  "holderDid": "{holderDID}"
}

 

Issuer processes credential requests:

The issuer receives the request in their inbox. They review, approve, and send back the requested VC(s) to the holder. Alternatively, they may have to first create the credential before sending it.

Automation Option: Issuers can preconfigure their wallet to auto-respond to requests - if the VC is already ready. However, if credentials are not yet generated, or if the holder requests a set of credentials where not all are available, manual intervention is required.

Holder receives VCs:

Once complete, the holder receives the VC, visible in the credential overview section of their admin app. 


 

API to Respond to VC Requests

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

Issuer Get Received Credential Requests

GET {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Response to VC Request -> Send Response to Request

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived/{requestId}/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Issuer-Initiated Credential Offer

Sometimes, the issuer wants to proactively notify holders that a credential is available or due for a refresh (e.g., before expiration or after key rotation). This issuing pattern is essential for refreshing credentials (e.g., after expiration or key revocation) because the issuer can push a new offer seamlessly, keeping the holder's status up to date with minimal friction.

Issuer sends offer

The issuer navigates their app to the relevant issued VC, opens the action menu, and sends a credential offer to the selected holder. The offer notifies the holder that a credential is prepped for them and can be retrieved.

Holder receives offer

The holder's wallet receives the offer. Here, behavior depends on their wallet's configuration:

  • Manual: The holder reviews the offer and chooses to make a credential request to receive it.
  • Automated: If the holder has marked the issuer as trusted with auto-accept enabled, the wallet will automatically convert the offer into a credential request and handle the entire transfer without manual clicks.

API to Offer VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

 

POST {div_wallet_srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "credentials": [
    "{vcId}"
  ]
}

 

Flexible Automation for Different Needs

A core strength of DIV is its support for both manual and automated flows. Depending on policy, user preference, and business process, any step on either issuer or holder side can be handled by a human or managed entirely by the wallet’s auto-configuration. In highly regulated or sensitive use-cases, both sides might want maximum manual review steps before issuing or accepting credentials. In high-scale, low-touch environments, the entire process can be embedded and fully automated.

 

Summary

Decentralized identity verification, enables seamless, secure transfer of verifiable credentials across wallet tenants. Whether initiated by holders seeking new credentials or by proactive issuers keeping credentials fresh, DCP allows maximum flexibility for both manual and automated workflows letting each participant tailor the process to their risk profile and user experience needs.

Read more

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Requesting VCs, Offering VCs
  • API documentation in detail
  • Decentralized Claims Protocol

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #4 in the Series
entry.content:
We’ve been talking in this about how you can build your business case for modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. However, many organizations still need help calculating the business value of migrating their database to the cloud.

A recent IDC study [1]  confirmed the value of modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. Using a detailed business value assessmt methodology, IDC calculated that each SAP HANA Cloud database delivered US$820,000 in average annual benefits, with a 10.3-month payback on investment. Numbers like that are sure to turn heads.

This blog reviews the three beneficial features that can help you make the case for SAP HANA Cloud: native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines the duties of database developers and administrators.

Native AI capabilities

To gain value from huge volumes of business data, you need advanced AI capabilities that simplify the development and deployment of intelligent applications. 

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, which offers powerful AI tools, frameworks, and services. These capabilities streamline the development and deployment of intelligent applications using machine learning and generative AI features. Extensive tools and resources, including prebuilt AI models, help you take advantage of business-ready AI.  

Multi-model engines process vast amounts of data and generate intelligent, in-context outputs. SAP HANA Cloud provides native storage, processing, and querying capabilities for AI data. A built-in vector engine handles embeddings as core data, so you can conduct similarity searches and rankings without creating separate vector databases. The database also supports retrieval-augmented generation, which helps large language models become more context-aware and integrate sensitive business context into data interactions.

SAP HANA Cloud also includes built-in, AI-enabled analytics that support predictive modeling, graph and similarity search, and time-series analysis. A predictive analysis library supports powerful features such as clustering, recommender systems, and outlier detection.  In addition, a library of 100+ business and scientific algorithms for key ML scenarios is embedded natively into the database. The IDC report suggests organizations can use these capabilities to automate insights and optimize decision-making by processing multiple data types. Study participants realized a 25% productivity increase, which translates into a value of $271,184 per enterprise.

Global cosmetics leader Natura &Co used the AI capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to create a similarity search. The vector engine feature of SAP HANA Cloud allows users to extract information from large volumes of documents using natural language. The company also plans to use the generative AI capability to streamline business processes and support faster decision-making in its implementation of SAP S/4HANA.

Built-in data integration

Your IT landscape is complex—with data flowing to and from multiple systems, cloud platforms, and on-premises environments. Bringing this data together has always required complex ETL processes, synchronization mechanisms, and data duplication efforts. How can you simplify the integration of this business data? Realistically, every business uses data sources provided by various vendors. To bring this data together requires smooth data integration.

SAP HANA Cloud offers native connectivity with almost any data source. You can access data from SAP and third-party applications, including ERP systems, IoT devices, and external data services. The database can gain live access to sources without data replication. This integration unifies disparate data streams and creates one holistic view of your enterprise data, allowing developers to build intelligent data applications that deliver accurate, current information in real time.  

Built-in data integration capabilities include:

  • Smart data access, offering virtual data access from source systems without physical data movement
  • Simple switching between virtual data access and data replication, balancing cost and performance effectively
  • Smart data integration, enabling real-time or batch data replication with transformation capabilities
  • Hybrid connectivity, with unified connection to on-premises SAP HANA systems

Multi-model capabilities combine federated relational data with other data types, including vector embedding, spatial information, graph relationships, and JSON documents. By eliminating traditional barriers between data sources and locations, SAP HANA Cloud helps you simplify data management while creating a connected enterprise data ecosystem.

In the IDC report, respondents said the ability to gain access to real-time data from a single source helped their analytics teams accelerate data reporting. One executive working in the retail industry said, “The data is far more accessible and quicker to get with SAP HANA Cloud.”

Automation to streamline DBA duties

The workload of database developers and administrators seems to grow endlessly, as data architectures become more complex. Whether they are diagnosing and resolving issues, tuning database performance, or writing queries, these workers face a long list of highly manual tasks.

Using integrated, AI-powered tooling available with SAP HANA Cloud helps administrators work more efficiently and productively. Conversational AI features help them generate SQL statements from plain text queries, create intelligent explanations of database behaviors or issues, and automatically summarize alerts and system messages into actionable insights.

SAP HANA Cloud also automates routine database maintenance issues. The database continuously monitors system usage and offers proactive recommendations for optimization. It can identify performance bottlenecks, guide resource tuning, and suggest areas ripe for elastic scaling. Administrators can get the job done with no deep technical intervention required. 

The benefits of automation are notable. In the IDC study, companies reported a 30% efficiency boost for their database administrator (DBA) teams, resulting in an average annual business value of $336,089 per organization.

One technology organization appreciated this value. “SAP HANA Cloud provides our DBA team with more tools to help identify issues and resolve them,” said the participant. “It has increased their productivity as a result.”

Another company in the agriculture industry concurred. “The fact that SAP HANA Cloud has centralized database administration and provided flexibility to add a data lake within its data source connections has positively impacted the productivity of our DBA team,” the executive added.

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the final blog to learn how comprehensive security and a complete development system can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

 

Additional resources:

What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1]  “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: UPC gana el primer puesto en el ULatinHack 2025 con proyecto de optimización energética
entry.content:
LinkedIn post: Post | Feed | LinkedIn

El pasado 10 de septiembre de 2025, el campus UPC Monterrico (Bancalari) fue sede de la cuarta edición del ULatinHack 2025, el hackatón más importante de Latinoamérica, que este año tuvo como eje temático la “Optimización de Consumo Energético”.

En esta edición participaron 466 inscritos, 117 equipos de 11 universidades de la región y, tras una intensa competencia, el primer puesto fue para el equipo “DevBug”, conformado por cinco estudiantes de la carrera de Ingeniería de Sistemas de Información de la UPC.

Su proyecto, titulado “Gestor de Energía Inteligente con Tecnología SAP”, destacó por su innovación y su aplicación práctica en la optimización de recursos energéticos, haciendo uso de SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) y SAP Analytics Cloud.

El jurado estuvo conformado por:

  • Cezar Manechini, Solution Advisory Head SAP BTP, Latin America
  • Luis Felipe Fernandini, Director Práctica SAP en NTT DATA Perú
  • Samuel Juarez Pulache, Director de Tecnología de la Información, Growbiz
  • Alejandra Vargas Santa Cruz, Coordinadora de Ingeniería de Sistemas EPE

Desde la UPC felicitamos a nuestros estudiantes por su dedicación y talento, que una vez más demuestran el nivel de excelencia de nuestra formación académica y nuestro compromiso con la innovación tecnológica.

¡Prepárate para la próxima edición y vive la experiencia de crear soluciones con tecnología SAP junto a estudiantes de toda Latinoamérica!

Saludos,

SAP University Alliances
